Here are our picks for the 4 best kids shampoo brands and choices, all of which are non-toxic and packed with moisturizing and nourishing natural ingredients When I became a parent, my first instinct was to use the same shampoo, [conditioner](https://greenactivefamily.com/nursery/bath-time/best-baby-conditioner/), [detangler](https://greenactivefamily.com/nursery/baby-care/best-detangler-for-kids-non-toxic/), and [lotion](https://greenactivefamily.com/nursery/baby-care/organic-natural-baby-lotion/) I remember from my own childhood. Before hitting the buy button, however, I did a bit of research and checked in with my mom friends. And I'm so happy I did! As it turns out, there are some ingredients in major baby shampoo brands that I'm just not comfortable using with my own baby. Unspecified ingredients like "fragrance" really concern me, because there's no way of knowing exactly what component ingredients go into making that fragrance. And with fragrance, there are often [phthalates](https://greenactivefamily.com/chemicals-and-materials/go-phthalate-free/) (suspected endocrine disruptors). Now that I'm a full time parenting writer, I am hyper aware of how personal care products like shampoo, conditioner, bar soap and body wash, [bubble bath](https://greenactivefamily.com/nursery/bath-time/homemade-bubble-bath-for-kids/), lotions - heck, even [laundry detergent](https://greenactivefamily.com/healthy-home/why-homemade-laundry-detergent/), [cleaners](https://greenactivefamily.com/healthy-home/green-cleaning/best-fragrance-free-cleaning-products/), and [dish soap](https://greenactivefamily.com/healthy-home/green-cleaning/best-dish-soap-for-baby-bottles/) - could effect my family's health in a negative way. Because of that, I now look for non-toxic, plant based baby shampoos with natural ingredients, in addition to other environmentally-safer choices like choosing [glass bottles](https://greenactivefamily.com/healthy-home/feeding/best-baby-bottles-glass-silicone-stainless-steel/) and [sippy cups](https://greenactivefamily.com/healthy-home/feeding/best-glass-sippy-cups-alternatives/), and [plastic free baby spoons](https://greenactivefamily.com/healthy-home/feeding/best-baby-spoons-self-feeding/). Today, I want to share that information with you. I hope it helps you make better decisions and find the safest baby shampoo for your own little ones, as well as natural shampoo for kids that are a bit older, too. The Best Natural Kids Shampoo: Natural Ingredients You Can Feel Good About I put this list together by consulting a few different resources. Most importantly, I've used the Environmental Working Group's (EWG) [Skin Deep Database](https://www.ewg.org/skindeep/) to ensure the kids shampoo I've included is non-toxic, and the safest possible. EWG rates products on a scale of 1 to 10, with 1 being the safest, and 10 being the most concerning. In addition to the 1 to 10 scale, EWG also has a EWG VERIFIED mark, which means the product meets the strictest ingredient and manufacturing standards. EWG VERIFIED products don't contain any ingredients the EWG has identified as unacceptable. I'm pretty strict about the personal care products I use with my own daughter, and really only want to use products that are the safest. That's also why I make my own [soap playdough](https://greenactivefamily.com/nursery/bath-time/diy-play-doh-soap-recipe/) and [bath finger paints](https://greenactivefamily.com/nursery/bath-time/diy-bath-paints/). As such, I've only included products ranked as EWG VERIFIED (the very best) or 1/10 (the safest rating other than EWG VERIFIED). I've also looked at EWG's ratings of component ingredients for hazard ratings. Worth noting, all of the clean kids shampoo I've included on this list are available on Amazon. I don't have a lot of time for shopping, so do tend to order a lot of my basics via [Amazon Prime](https://www.amazon.com/tryprimefree?ref_=assoc_tag_ph_1427739975520&_encoding=UTF8&camp=1789&creative=9325&linkCode=pf4&tag=greenactive-20&linkId=a96ed55f1d9abe43fa8b984b7a37ab05), and suspect a lot of other parents are the same! Also worth noting, companies sometimes change formulations - I've done my best to ensure this is correct at the time of writing, but it's subject to change. If in doubt, I definitely think you should the Environmental Working Group's (EWG) [Skin Deep Database](https://www.ewg.org/skindeep/) yourself - it's a great resource! At the end of the day, this is just my opinion, and you'll have to form your own! The Benefits of Using Organic Children's Shampoos Choosing more natural, organic ingredients for the products your kids and family use can make a big difference in terms of reducing exposure to a range of harmful chemicals found in everyday products. Opting for kids organic shampoos, soaps, and other personal care products means, you can focus on buying natural, pure, and healthy ingredients that are gentle on the scalp and hair, and free from harsh chemicals. As a baseline, most non-toxic kids shampoos are free from parabens, sulfates, phthalates, and other synthetic fragrances. If you prefer scented products to fragrance-free, look for a natural scent, such as essential oil. They also tend to be free from synthetic dyes, artificial colors, and other harsh ingredients. Kids shampoo, in particular, is designed to be gentle on the scalp and hair, and to help keep the hair healthy, shiny, and soft. It is often enriched with natural oils, vitamins, and minerals to nourish the scalp and hair. Organic kids shampoo is usually hypoallergenic, which means it is less likely to cause an allergic reaction. More specifically, many are free from common allergens such as gluten, soy, and dairy. Some brands are also biodegradable, making it a more sustainable and eco-friendly choice for for the environment when compared to conventional shampoos. Finally, many of the options are also cruelty-free, with no animal testing (some are also vegan). Natural and Organic Ingredients Commonly Found in Children's Shampoos Organic shampoos typically used natural, organic ingredients. Below, you'll find some that are gentle and effective for hair and scalp health, and may be a good choice for kid's shampoo. These include (but aren't limited to): Aloe Vera Aloe Vera is [beneficial for hair and scalp health](https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Sana-Noreen/publication/342588964_A_Close_Look_at_Aloe_Vera_Barbadensis_and_It's_Effect_on_Hair_Health/links/5efc25d492851c52d60ca18d/A-Close-Look-at-Aloe-Vera-Barbadensis-and-Its-Effect-on-Hair-Health.pdf). It has soothing and moisturizing properties, is gentle, and can help leave your child's hair softer and smoother (which is great for tangles). Chamomile Chamomile has [anti-inflammatory and anti-septic properties](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3210003/), and helps soothe an itchy scalp. It's also said to promote healthy hair growth. Coconut Oil Coconut Oil is rich in fatty acids that can help to nourish and moisturize your child's hair. It has also been [shown to prevent breakage from combing](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/12715094/), helping to leave it soft and shiny. Lavender Lavender is well-known for its ability to help calm and relax. It's a great choice for the pre-bedtime bath routine. However, pure lavender essential oil has also been [shown to promote hair growth](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4843973/), and has even been [shown to repel head lice!](https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/j.1365-4632.2007.03132.x) Jojoba Oil Jojoba oil has a similar chemical structure to the natural oils produced by our scalps, making it a great choice for nourishing [and moisturizing](https://www.sidemast.org/download/sidemast_20140401124048.pdf#page=137) a dry scalp and hair. Shea Butter Shea butter has been used in cosmetics, including hair care, [for thousands of years.](https://www.healthline.com/health/shea-butter-for-hair) It's rich, oily composition makes an excellent moisturizer. Despite a lack of peer-reviewed studies investigating its benefits in hair care, it's anecdotally known to be leave hair feeling soft and shiny. Tea Tree Oil Tea tree oil has antibacterial and anti-fungal properties, and is [particularly effective for dandruff](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/12451368/). It has a strong, invigorating scent that some children might not love, and for this reason it's less commonly found in children's shampoos. Argan Oil Argan oil is acids (oleic, linoleic, palmitic, and stearic acids) that prevent breakage, and has also been [shown to be an effective and healthy antioxidant](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3723062/). In practical terms, it can help reduce frizziness, and is best used as pure argan oil. Calendula Calendula is a gentle ingredient that has anti-fungal properties helpful in dealing with dandruff. It's also well known as a soothing ingredient. Ingredients Common in Normal Children's Shampoo vs Organic Sulphates Sulphates are a popular "avoid" ingredient these days, and [the sulphate-free shampoo trend](https://www.emergenresearch.com/industry-report/sulfate-free-shampoo-market) is growing. Sulphates are a surfactant that create lather and bubbles in shampoo (and other products, such as soap and detergent). Despite having a bad reputation, the EU, [Health Canada](https://www.canada.ca/en/health-canada/services/consumer-product-safety/cosmetics/labelling/safety-ingredients.html#a4.13), and FDA in the US all consider sulphates safe for cosmetic use. So why the bad reputation? As it turns out, sulphates are extremely effective at washing away dirt and oils. In other words? They can strip a bit too much out. For kids with sensitive skin, it can create more itching and irritation, which is why gentler alternatives are becoming more common. Parabens Parabens have been shown to [slightly disrupt hormones](https://www.tandfonline.com/doi/abs/10.1080/10408440490920104), [may effect reproductivity,](https://hero.epa.gov/hero/index.cfm/reference/details/reference_id/1407048) can irritate skin, and have been [found in breast tumours](https://analyticalsciencejournals.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/abs/10.1002/jat.958). Health Canada is currently reviewing parabens as food additives, and has concluded that [some parabens may pose a risk](https://www.canada.ca/en/health-canada/services/chemicals-product-safety/parabens.html) to human health. Phthalates [Phthalates are an "everywhere chemical" ](https://greenactivefamily.com/chemicals-and-materials/go-phthalate-free/)commonly used in cosmetics and personal care products, such as soap and shampoo/conditioner. Often, it's not a listed ingredient, but rather hidden within other ingredients - in particular, synthetic fragrance. Phthalates are a known endochrine disruptor and have been found to be correlated with social deficits, asthma, and ADHD. Frequently Asked Questions Healthcare professionals, including [the American Academy of Dermatology](https://www.aad.org/public/everyday-care/hair-scalp-care/hair/wash-hair), recommend parents consider their child's hair type, age, and activity level when deciding how often they should wash their hair. Different hair types require different frequency of washing. Oily hair, straight hair, and fine hair types need to be washed more often. For pre-teens approaching puberty or those who have entered puberty, the AAD recommends washing it daily or every second day, depending on activity levels. For kids who are younger, once to twice per week is likely enough. Kids with dry hair, curly hair, or African American hair tend to need less frequent washes. Once every 7 to 10 days is a good rule of thumb, although it should be rinsed and conditioned after sweating or swimming. Medium hair and wavy hair falls somewhere in between. If you notice your child's hair or scalp is getting oily, or you notice a distinctive hair odor with your current routine, add an extra shampoo each week until you've solved the issue. If their hair is dull or dry, reduce shampoos by once per week until you've restored balance. Using a specifically formulated kids shampoo instead of adult shampoo is a good choice for your children. Kids shampoo formulations tend to milder and gentler, which is more suitable for kids' sensitive skin and scalps. It also tends to be less drying, and less likely to strip away the hair's natural oils. Importantly, kids shampoo also tends to be "tear free." That means it doesn't - or at least is less likely to - cause eye irritation or stinging if it gets in your little one's eyes during lathering or rinsing. When it comes to the ingredients label, kids shampoo also tends to have safer ingredients, although it's worth checking the label yourself to be sure.
